description: Panama offers a compelling fiscal environment with its territorial tax system and dollarized economy, making it a top choice for retirees prioritizing affordability. The cost of living (Index: 44.3) is significantly lower than in North America, and the Pensionado program provides unmatched benefits. However, prospective residents should be aware that safety (Index: 52.7) and English proficiency (Low) can be hurdles outside of expat bubbles, requiring some cultural adjustment compared to more developed hubs.

visas.name: 180-Day Visa Waiver for Tourists
visas.description: Short‑term entry permission that allows eligible visitors to enter Panama for a limited stay by presenting a valid passport, proof of return or onward travel, and proof of sufficient funds.
requirements: Passport
Proof of return
Proof of sufficient funds

visas.name: Pensionado Visa
visas.description: Long‑term residency program aimed at retirees or pensioners; applicants must show a lifetime pension of at least $1,000 per month or qualify through the purchase of Panamanian real estate valued at $100,000 or more.
requirements: Must be a retiree or pensioner with a lifetime pension of at least $1,000 per month.
Purchase real estate in Panama valued at $100,000 or more

visas.name: Friendly Nations Visa
visas.description: Residency option for citizens of qualifying nations; applicants must prove economic or professional ties to Panama—such as employment, business activity, or real estate—and open a Panamanian bank account with at least $5,000 USD.
requirements: Must show proof of economic and professional ties to Panama (this can be employment, business, purchase of real estate)
You must also open a Panamanian bank account with a minimum balance of $5,000 USD.

description: Portugal balances high European living standards with a relatively moderate cost of living (Index: 45.8) compared to its northern neighbors. It stands out for its safety (Index: 67.6) and very high English proficiency (607), making integration easier for expats. While the tax burden can be higher than in Latin America—with progressive rates up to 48%—the quality of healthcare (Index: 72.0) and infrastructure offers excellent value for those seeking stability and a mild, temperate climate.

visas.name: 180-Day Visa Waiver for Tourists
visas.description: Short-term entry permission that allows eligible visitors to enter Portugal for a limited stay by presenting a valid passport, proof of return or onward travel, and proof of sufficient funds.
requirements: Passport
Proof of return or onward ticket
Proof of sufficient funds

visas.name: Short-Stay Visa for Remote Workers
visas.description: Visa designed for digital nomads and remote workers, allowing individuals employed by foreign companies to live and work in Portugal temporarily while meeting income and documentation requirements.
requirements: For people who work remotely for employers or clients outside Portugal
Minimum monthly income requirement: $3,300 USD or $4,900 USD (if you have dependents)
You must prove employment and income

visas.name: Retirement (D7) Visa
visas.description: Long-term residency visa intended for retirees and passive income earners; applicants must demonstrate stable income and residence in Portugal, with the opportunity to transition to permanent residency after five years.
requirements: Must be a retiree, pensioner, or person with passive income (such as investments, rent, or savings) of at least $820 USD per month
Proof of accommodation in Portugal (rental agreement or property ownership)
Valid health insurance

visas.name: Golden Visa Program
visas.description: Residency program for investors who make qualifying investments in Portugal’s economy, offering a path to permanent residency and citizenship after five years.
requirements: Minimum investment of $540,000 USD in real estate or $380,000 USD in research, cultural projects, or investment funds
Must maintain the investment for a minimum of 5 years
Clean criminal record and valid health insurance

visas.name: Startup / Business Visa
visas.description: Residency visa for entrepreneurs and innovators seeking to develop or invest in business ventures in Portugal, designed to attract talent and foster economic growth.
requirements: Must establish or co-own a startup or innovative business project in Portugal
Proof of sufficient financial means to support living expenses
Approval from Startup Portugal or an incubator program

description: Costa Rica is a biodiversity hotspot that attracts expats with its political stability and high-quality healthcare (Index: 61.2). While it offers a tropical lifestyle, it is one of the pricier Central American destinations, with a cost of living index (50.3) noticeably higher than neighboring Panama. Safety is moderate (Index: 46.3), requiring awareness in urban areas, but the territorial tax system and established residency options like the Pensionado program continue to make it a primary choice for nature-loving retirees.

visas.name: Tourist Entry
visas.description: Entry permission allowing U.S. and Canadian citizens to visit Costa Rica for up to 180 days without a visa, provided they can show proof of onward travel and adequate financial means.
requirements: Valid passport
Return or onward ticket
Proof of sufficient funds (minimum of $100 per month of intended stay)

visas.name: Digital Nomad Visa
visas.description: A visa designed for remote workers who earn income from foreign sources. It allows an initial one-year stay, with an option to extend for another year if at least six months are spent in the country during the first year.
requirements: Must work remotely for an employer or clients outside Costa Rica
Minimum monthly income of $3,000

visas.name: Pensionado Residency
visas.description: A long-term residency program for retirees who can demonstrate a permanent monthly pension income of at least $1,000. The residency is valid for two years and renewable.
requirements: Proof of lifetime pension income of at least $1,000 per month

visas.name: Rentista Residency
visas.description: A two-year renewable residency program for individuals with reliable income or deposited savings sufficient to sustain living expenses in Costa Rica.
requirements: Proof of guaranteed income of $2,500 per month for at least two years
Deposit of $60,000 in a Costa Rican bank account

visas.name: Inversionista Residency
visas.description: Long-term residency for investors who commit qualifying capital to Costa Rica’s economy. The permit is valid for two years and can be renewed if the investment is maintained.
requirements: Minimum investment of $150,000 in a business, property, or other approved Costa Rican venture

description: Mexico is a vibrant North American destination that offers a compelling mix of modern amenities and traditional culture at a low cost. Its cost of living index (37.6) and affordable healthcare (Index: 72.7) make it a top tier choice for retirees. While it boasts a warm, tropical climate and a massive expat community of over 8 million, prospective residents must navigate a high corruption index (26) and moderate safety concerns (Index: 46.8). However, the wide availability of residency visas and proximity to the US remain major draws.

visas.name: Temporary Resident Visa
visas.description: This visa permits foreign nationals to enter Mexico and remain in the territory under temporary resident status for purposes specified by immigration law. The foreigner’s purpose is to remain in Mexico for a period longer than 180 days and not longer than 4 years.
requirements: Valid passport
Must present at an authorized port of entry for foreign nationals whose purpose is to stay in Mexico under temporary resident status.

visas.name: Permanent Resident Visa
visas.description: A visa for foreign nationals who wish to enter Mexico as permanent residents; it grants indefinite residence status once issued.
requirements: Valid passport, original and copy.
Proof of legal stay if applicable (for those already in Mexico under temporary status).
Either proof of retired or pensioned status, or family unity (having Mexican citizen or legal permanent resident family member) or points-based eligibility.
Submission of the immigration application within the first 30 calendar days of entry under the visa.

visas.name: Temporary Resident Student Visa
visas.description: This visa is granted to foreign nationals who plan to enter Mexico as temporary resident students for studies lasting more than 180 days. It requires a valid passport, proof of legal stay if applicable, documents showing acceptance or enrollment in studies, and the completed visa application with a compliant photo.
requirements: Valid passport or travel document recognized under international law
Proof of legal stay, if the applicant is not a national of the country where the visa application is made
Proof of enrollment or acceptance at a recognized educational institution, or documentation showing participation under an international student-exchange or mobility agreement.
Completed visa application form, printed on a single sheet, double-sided.

description: France is a world-renowned destination for those seeking culture, cuisine, and a high quality of life. It offers excellent healthcare (Index: 77.2) and a strong social safety net, reflected in a high life expectancy at 65 (22+ years). However, this premium lifestyle comes at a cost; the cost of living index (64.4) and tax rates are significantly higher than in developing nations. While safety is generally moderate (Index: 44.4), the rich history and central European location make it an enduring favorite for refined retirement.

visas.name: Short-Stay Visit (Tourist/90-day)
visas.description: Visitors from certain countries may enter France with this type of visa for up to 90 days at a time; U.S. and French reciprocal treaty allows for an additional 90 days in some cases.
requirements: Valid passport (at least 1 year validity) for North Americans.
Up to 90-day stay in France for visitors from certain countries (e.g., U.S., Canada).

visas.name: Long-Stay Visa (Visa de Long Séjour)
visas.description: The standard visa for those wanting to live, retire, or stay in France beyond the short-stay period; though France does not offer a specific “retirement visa”, the Long- Stay “Visitor” visa is suited for retirees or passive-income holders.
requirements: Must submit a written statement agreeing not to seek employment in France (specifically for the “Visitor” category).
Proof of sufficient financial means, health insurance, and proof of accommodation required (for Visitor variant).

visas.name: Permanent Residency Path (Carte de Séjour / Residence Renewal)
visas.description: After living in France on a long-stay visa and meeting renewal conditions, you may obtain a residence card (Carte de Séjour); over time you may move toward long- term or permanent status.
requirements: After arriving with a long-stay visa, you must validate it online (via OFII) and apply for renewal.
In the first year you must complete required processes including health examination via OFII.
Renewal needed each year until you qualify for longer-term residence cards; you must renew three months before expiry of your long-stay visa.

description: Spain combines a relaxed Mediterranean lifestyle with modern European infrastructure. It is highly regarded for its excellent healthcare (Index: 77.3) and high safety levels (Index: 62.8). The cost of living (Index: 48.6) is moderate for Western Europe, offering good value for retirees. While English proficiency is moderate (535), the welcoming culture and established expat communities make integration feasible. The 'Non-Lucrative Visa' is a popular choice for retirees with passive income.

visas.name: Tourist Stay (Schengen Short-Stay)
visas.description: Visitors from many countries (including the U.S. and Canada) may enter Spain without a long-stay visa for up to 90 days during any 180-day window; this route is for short-term stays only and cannot be used for applying for residency from within Spain.
requirements: Valid passport (often visa-free for up to 90 days within a 180-day period).
Entry under Schengen rules for up to 90 days during any 180-day period.

visas.name: Non-Lucrative Visa
visas.description: A residency route for persons who have passive income (such as pensions, dividends or investments) and wish to live in Spain long-term without working; the visa is valid for one year and renewable for two-year periods as long as requirements are maintained.
requirements: Applicants must demonstrate an annual income of at least €30,000.
Health insurance and a clean criminal record.
Medical certificate showing no communicable diseases.
Applicants may not engage in professional or economic activities in Spain.

visas.name: Digital Nomad Visa
visas.description: A visa designed for remote workers who want to live in Spain while working for foreign (non-Spanish) employers; valid up to one year and renewable for up to five years under certain conditions.
requirements: Non-EU/EEA nationals working remotely for employers or clients outside Spain, with no more than 20% of income derived from Spanish sources.
Applicants generally need to prove a stable income of around €2,000–€2,500/month, though amounts may vary slightly.

visas.name: Investor Visa (Golden Visa)
visas.description: A residency route for investors willing to make significant investments in Spain (real estate, companies, funds or bonds); allows initial two-year permit followed by five-year residency and counts toward permanent residency/citizenship under certain conditions.
requirements: Purchase real estate in Spain worth at least €500,000.
Or invest €1 million in Spanish bank deposits or Spanish companies.
Or invest €2 million in Spanish government bonds.

visas.name: Permanent Residency
visas.description: After meeting residency and stay conditions under a long-term visa route, foreigners can apply for permanent residency in Spain, which grants the right to work and live indefinitely in the country.
requirements: Qualifying applicants (from non-lucrative, digital nomad or investor visas) can apply after five uninterrupted years of residency (of which at least four years must be spent in Spain).

description: Malaysia offers a unique blend of modern development and tropical affordability. It boasts a high safety index (62.8) and quality healthcare (Index: 70.7) at very low costs. The cost of living is attractive (Index: 48.6) with exceptionally cheap dining options (Restaurant Index: 22.6 in some regions, though here noted higher). English is widely spoken (High proficiency), facilitating easy communication. The MM2H (Malaysia My Second Home) program is a well-known option for long-term residency, making it a gateway to Southeast Asia.

visas.name: Temporary Visa (for North-American visitors)
visas.description: Visitors from North America may enter Malaysia without a visa and stay for up to three months under the standard temporary visitor arrangement.
requirements: No visa required for North American visitors; stays up to three months after arrival.

visas.name: Multiple Entry Visa
visas.description: A visa option for business-visiting foreign nationals, allowing multiple entries into Malaysia for periods of three to twelve months depending on business activities.
requirements: Issued to foreign nationals who require a visa for business purposes.
Valid for three to twelve months, depending on the nature of your business.

visas.name: Residence Pass-Talent (RP-T)
visas.description: A 10-year renewable pass for highly qualified foreign professionals to live and work in Malaysia under flexible conditions, including job-change eligibility and inclusion of spouses.
requirements: Designed for highly qualified expats.
Includes spouses of the pass holder, and allows the spouse to seek employment without needing a separate Employment Pass.

visas.name: Permanent Residency
visas.description: A pathway to indefinite residence in Malaysia available to select foreign nationals satisfying high value, expertise, or family sponsorship criteria; grants full residency rights once approved.
requirements: Available to high-net-worth individuals, experts in specific fields, certain professionals, and the spouse of a Malaysian citizen.
Applicants must score 65 points out of 120 in a points-based system.
Must have a Malaysian sponsor.
Must present a certificate of good conduct from country of origin.

description: Greece offers a relaxed Mediterranean lifestyle with historic charm and stunning landscapes. It is a stable destination (Fragile States Index: 54.7) with a moderate cost of living (Index: 51.0). The 'Golden Visa' program is a major attraction for investors seeking EU residency. Healthcare is decent (Index: 58.5) but varies by region. With very high English proficiency (602) and a welcoming culture, it is an accessible choice for those looking to enjoy island life or mainland history.

visas.name: Tourist Entry (Schengen Short-Stay)
visas.description: Visitors may stay in Greece for up to 90 days without a long-term visa.
requirements: Valid passport.
Up to 90 days stay for many nationalities under tourist status.

visas.name: National D-Visa (Long-Stay Visa)
visas.description: A national visa (category D) for stays longer than 90 days, to be followed by application for a residence permit.
requirements: Apply from a Greek consulate/embassy in your home country.
File for a residence permit once in Greece before the visa expires.

visas.name: Financially Independent Person (FIP) Permit
visas.description: A residency permit for retirees or persons with passive income, without work rights, valid for three years and renewable under same conditions.
requirements: Minimum monthly passive income of €3,500 for the main applicant.
Additional €700/month for spouse.
Additional €525/month per dependent child.
Permanent visa does not require minimum stay in Greece.
Cannot engage in employment or economic activity in Greece.

visas.name: Digital Nomad Visa / Residence Permit
visas.description: For remote workers who wish to live in Greece while working for employers/clients outside Greece; includes two-year residence permit renewable under conditions.
requirements: Minimum post-tax monthly income of €3,500 from sources outside Greece.
Additional 20% for spouse; additional 15% for each child.
Hold initial national D-Visa, then convert to a two-year residence permit.
Proof that your work is remote and not for a Greek employer.

visas.name: Golden Visa / Investor Residency
visas.description: Residency via investment in Greece allowing long-term stay and eventually permanent residency; property investment levels vary by location and type of property.
requirements: Purchase real-estate investment: • €800,000 in prime areas (Athens, Mykonos, Santorini, Thessaloniki). • €400,000 elsewhere in Greece.
• €250,000 in islands with population <10,000 or when renovating commercial/historic properties.
Investment must be in a single property as of Sept 2024.
Clean criminal record, health insurance for applicant and family.

visas.name: Permanent Residency
visas.description: After five years of legal long-term residency, applicants may apply for permanent residency status in Greece.
requirements: Have lived in Greece for 5 years on a long-term visa.

visas.name: Citizenship by Naturalization
visas.description: Naturalization route giving Greek citizenship enables full rights including EU mobility after meeting residence and integration criteria.
requirements: Seven consecutive years of residency (three years for EU nationals or those married to Greek citizens).
Must be over 18, have no criminal record.
Pass written exam on Greek geography, culture, history and oral exam for Greek language proficiency.
Demonstrate integration and contributions to community.

description: Italy is a globally celebrated destination that offers a lifestyle centered on culture, history, and world-class cuisine. It provides high-quality healthcare (Index: 64.9) and a long life expectancy (21+ years at 65). However, living here comes with a higher price tag than in developing nations (Cost of Living Index: 57.2) and a complex bureaucracy. Safety is generally moderate (Index: 52.8), and while English proficiency is moderate (535), the rich social fabric and "dolce vita" lifestyle continue to make it a top choice for retirees seeking European charm.

visas.name: Temporary Visa (Short-Stay Tourist/Business)
visas.description: Entry for short visits to Italy (tourism or business) for up to 90 days; no visa needed for North Americans per the page. Longer stays require moving to a long-term visa/residence permit track.
requirements: Valid passport
Stay up to 90 days if the purpose is tourism or business (for North American citizens; as stated on the page)
For stays longer than 90 days, a long-term residence permit is required

visas.name: Investor Visa (Italy)
visas.description: Italy’s “Investor Visa” allows non-EU nationals to obtain long-term residency by making one of several specified investment or donation options in Italy; once approved, the resident receives a Permesso di Soggiorno and may eventually qualify for permanent residency.
requirements: Invest at least €2 million in Italian government bonds.
Or invest at least €500,000 in an Italian company.
Or invest at least €250,000 in an Italian innovative start-up.
Or donate at least €1 million to philanthropic causes in Italy.

visas.name: Permanent Residency (Long-Term EU Residence Permit)
visas.description: After five years of legal residency under a valid visa and permit, a foreign national in Italy may apply for the “Long-Term EU Residence Permit” which grants indefinite residency rights, similar to permanence.
requirements: Must have legally resided in Italy for at least five years with a valid visa and residence permit.
Must have a clean criminal record.
Must have Italian-language proficiency to A2 level.
Must continue to have sufficient income to support yourself and dependents.

visas.name: Citizenship by Naturalization
visas.description: After meeting legal-residency and integration requirements, foreign nationals may apply for Italian citizenship through naturalization; those with Italian ancestry may follow a faster route depending on their documentation.
requirements: Must have legally resided in Italy for 10 years (for non-EU nationals) before application.
Must have Italian-language proficiency to B1 level.
Must demonstrate integration into Italian society through documentation such as cultural knowledge, residence, and activity in Italy.
For those who can show Italian ancestry, the process may take 3-6 years depending on documentation quality and relationship.

visas.name: National Visa (Long-Stay Visa for Non-EU Nationals)
visas.description: This long-stay type visa enables non-EU nationals to travel to Italy for stays longer than 90 days; once in Italy, they must obtain a residence permit (Permesso di Soggiorno) to live and/or study/work legally.
requirements: Apply for a national visa (type D) at an Italian consulate in home country.
Receive a residence permit (Permesso di Soggiorno) after arrival in Italy.
Valid for long-stay permissions beyond 90 days.

description: Thailand is a premier destination for those seeking an exotic lifestyle on a budget. It boasts an ultra-low cost of living (Index: 35.3) and high-quality healthcare (Index: 77.3), making it a favorite for medical tourism and retirement. The country offers a hot, tropical climate and incredible food culture (Restaurant Index: 22.0). While English proficiency is very low (416) outside tourist hubs and political stability is a consideration (Fragile States: Warning), the welcoming culture and specific visas like the 'Elite' or 'Long-Term Resident' programs make it highly accessible.

visas.name: Non-Immigrant O Visa (Retirement Visa)
visas.description: A long-term visa for retirees aged 50+ who wish to live in Thailand; it does not allow employment and requires proof of insurance and clean legal status.
requirements: Applicant must be 50 years or older.
Applicant must have health insurance that covers at least $1,190 for outpatient treatment and $11,900 for inpatient treatment while in Thailand.
Applicant must have no legal issues preventing entry into Thailand.

visas.name: Long-Term Resident Visa
visas.description: A long-stay visa option for applicants 50+ who meet higher financial thresholds and insurance requirements, allowing extended residency in Thailand.
requirements: Applicant must be aged 50 years or over.
Bank deposit of at least $90,000 in Thailand OR bank deposit of $55,000 + annual income of at least $36,000.
Health insurance that covers COVID-19, total sum insured at least $100,000 per year.

visas.name: Thailand Elite Visa
visas.description: A premium long-term visa scheme requiring membership in the Thailand Elite programme allows extended stays for up to five or ten years depending on the plan.
requirements: Hold a Thailand Elite Card (or Thailand Privilege Card).
Passport, two passport-size photos, visa application form, flight confirmation, official confirmation letter from Thailand Elite, medical insurance covering at least $10,000.

visas.name: Wealthy Pensioner Visa
visas.description: A specialized long-term residency visa for affluent retirees or pensioners who wish to live in Thailand, with higher income or investment thresholds and health/insurance prerequisites.
requirements: Passive income between $40,000 and $80,000 annually.
Investment of at least $250,000 in Thai government bonds, business, or property.
Health insurance coverage of at least $50,000 or a bank deposit of at least $100,000.

visas.name: Permanent Residency
visas.description: The pathway to indefinite residence in Thailand for select candidates who meet criteria for skills, investment, or long-term commitment; limited availability, with language and financial prerequisites.
requirements: Thailand issues only 100 permanent residence permits per country per year.
Application via employment, special skills, or investment of approximately $90,000 in the country.
Applicant must pass Thai-language test.
